original_title: Sri Lanka to strengthen deposit insurance with World Bank funds
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Cabinet of ministers has given policy approval for the implementation of a financial sector safety net project, with World Bank funds.
The World Bank will provide 150 million US dollars as a loan for this purpose.
The monies will be for capitalization of Sri Lanka deposit insurance scheme, institutional capacity development of the Central Bank and supervision of the implementation of that project.

The financial sector safety net project is designed to boost the financial and institutional capacity of the Sri Lanka Deposit Insurance Scheme (SLDIS), which is managed by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka.

“Sri Lanka’s economic crisis highlights the need for strong safety nets to support the financial sector. Stable and reliable banking sector is essential for the economy, businesses and individuals, small businesses and poor households,” Faris Hadad-Zervos, World Bank Country Director for Sri Lanka said in a statement after the agency’s board approved the 150 million US dollar credit in November. (Colombo/Dec6/2023)
Sri Lanka gets US$150mn from World Bank for deposit insurance
